Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Defensive chemistry underlying latitudinal patterns in plant-herbivore interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The distribution of crop pests is not constant in all places always. If scientists could predict where or when pests would be worst, it could prevent financial losses. This project will provide direct insight into the specific role of the environment (climate, summer length, etc.) on pest pressure. The researchers will address this question in a wild plant species rather than a crop species. This is because pesticides and agricultural practices hide the influence of natural factors. The focal species in this study is pokeweed (and associated pests). Pokeweed is a culturally significant perennial plant native to the eastern USA. Prior research has shown that pokeweed is heavily eaten by caterpillars in the southern vs. northern US. This proposal checks if pokeweed's defenses against insects are stronger in the South. That pattern would suggest that the plants in the South have adapted to a long history of stronger pest pressure. In addition, the research will answer basic questions about how the environment influences relationships between plants and insects. It will also help to address the long-standing mystery of why ecosystems closer to the equator have more species than ecosystems at higher latitudes. The project will also enhance K-12 education through the creation of videos on latitudinal diversity for distribution to teachers.

This project tests the hypothesis that plants are better chemically defended at lower latitudes. The researchers will use a generalist caterpillar (Spodoptera exigua) to bioassay defense, and correlate caterpillar performance with leaf traits. Preliminary trials show that mortality is greater for S. exigua raised on a diet of pokeweed leaves from lower vs. higher latitude plants, suggesting that low-latitude plants are better defended. Lower latitude leaves are tougher, so to disentangle mechanical and chemical defense traits, ground leaves will be incorporated into agar for bioassays that test the effects of chemical defenses only. Liquid and Gas Chromatography Mass Spectrometry will characterize leaf chemistry profiles, and the ratio of carbon to nitrogen will serve as an index of leaf nutritional value. In sum, the project asks which leaf traits predict caterpillar performance over a latitudinal gradient, advancing our understanding of geographic variation in plant defense and addressing recent controversy about the generality of stronger biotic interactions at lower latitudes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SUMMARY

The “biotic interactions hypothesis” predicts that interactions between species play a greater role in driving adaptation closer to the equator, where the climate is not as stressful as areas with harsh winters. This pattern could explain why biodiversity is so high in the tropics, because unlike the climate, species interactions can continuously evolve, quickly generating biodiversity. In particular, the “arms race” of evolution between plants and herbivores may be a major contributor to community diversity patterns, yet there is controversy about whether herbivory or plant defenses are more intense at lower latitudes (closer to the equator). Several studies, however, measure plant traits without testing the assumption that they are defensive; chemical defense in particular is challenging to compare between distantly related plants, so it is often not evaluated for latitudinal comparisons. Additionally, young leaves are rarely considered in latitudinal comparisons, but they are typically under greater herbivore pressure and strongly chemically defended compared to mature leaves.

We tested whether plants are better defended at lower latitudes using a pair of plants spanning over 30° latitude. The plants were Phytolacca americana (pokeweed) in the eastern US and P. rivinoides (jaboncillo) in Costa Rica. We measured multiple traits on both young and mature leaves that are hypothesized to function as plant defenses. Traits were measured in plants collected from 13 populations and grown in a common greenhouse environment. Leaves were fed to a caterpillar that can eat a wide range of different plants, Spodoptera exigua (beet armyworm), to evaluate which traits were associated with reducing herbivore growth. Traits included leaf chemistry (quantified with liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry), toughness, and nitrogen content. As predicted by the biotic interactions hypothesis, caterpillars grew larger when eating P. americana from higher latitudes, and they were smallest when eating young leaves of the tropical P. rivinoides. All traits varied with geography and leaf age, but only chemical composition and abundance were correlated with reduced caterpillar growth. By most measures these chemical traits supported the hypothesis of better-defended leaves at lower latitudes. Machine learning analysis found that saponins (soapy chemicals) were important for reducing caterpillar growth, and there were more saponins involved in defense of young than mature leaves.

 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The latitudinal diversity gradient is a long-standing biological puzzle, with many proposed hypotheses but few firm answers. Research is lacking for evolutionary hypotheses that explain why diversification rates may be faster at lower latitudes. The project rigorously tested the prediction that plants are better defended at latitudes. Our results highlight the importance of understanding defensive function of traits across leaf ages for testing the biotic interactions hypothesis; most studies on the topic focus only on mature leaves, which may show weaker latitudinal patterns than young leaves. Understanding the causes and consequences of variation in biotic interactions in a latitudinal context is the first step toward a more general exploration of how the abiotic environment affects the outcomes of biotic interactions, and in turn how variation in biotic interactions impacts biodiversity.

 

BROADER IMPACTS

The co-PI is a female scientist, and for this project she supervised six female undergraduate research assistants who worked on plant care, trait measurement, and preparing leaf samples for chemical analyses. Two of the students completed independent projects on related research questions under Baskett’s mentorship during the reporting period; their results were presented as posters at the University Undergraduate Research and Arts Forum at Michigan State University. Four of the five students who have graduated are either working in STEM-related jobs or continuing STEM-related post-graduate education.

As co-coordinator and teaching assistant of the undergraduate Ecology Lab course at Michigan State University, Baskett incorporated methods and results from this project in classroom lessons. The course includes group independent research projects, and six (of twelve) groups utilized P. americana seeds or caterpillar assays of plant defense for their projects. Additionally, she lectured about the results to demonstrate presentation of scientific research. Finally, Baskett is creating a Data Nugget based on this project (classroom exercise focused on developing quantitative skills). She is translating it to Spanish and will disseminate it using existing Data Nugget infrastructure.
